description: Practice the meanings of common phrasal verbs using definition matching questions.

questions.question: give up
questions.answer: To stop trying; to quit something.
questions.example: She decided to give up smoking for her health.
choices: To stop trying; to quit something.

questions.question: look up
questions.answer: To search for information.
questions.example: I need to look up this word in the dictionary.

questions.question: put off
questions.answer: To postpone something.
questions.example: The meeting was put off until next week.

questions.question: look after
questions.answer: To take care of someone or something.
questions.example: Can you look after the children while I'm at work?
choices: To take care of someone or something.

questions.question: turn down
questions.answer: To reduce the volume or intensity.
questions.example: Can you turn down the volume? It's too loud.
choices: To reduce the volume or intensity.

questions.question: take off
questions.answer: To remove clothing or to leave the ground (plane).
questions.example: Please take off your shoes before entering the house.
choices: To remove clothing or to leave the ground (plane).

questions.question: run into
questions.answer: To meet someone unexpectedly.
questions.example: I ran into my old friend at the grocery store.

questions.question: turn on
questions.answer: To activate or start a device.
questions.example: Please turn on the TV. I want to watch the news.
choices: To activate or start a device.

questions.question: run out
questions.answer: To use up all of something.
questions.example: The car ran out of gas on the highway.
choices: To use up all of something.

questions.question: get up
questions.answer: To rise from bed or a sitting position.
questions.example: I got up early this morning to go jogging.
choices: To rise from bed or a sitting position.
To use up all of something.

questions.question: put on
questions.answer: To wear or dress in clothing.
questions.example: She put on her jacket because it was cold.
choices: To wear or dress in clothing.
To use up all of something.

questions.question: hand in
questions.answer: To submit or deliver something.
questions.example: The teacher asked us to hand in our papers.

questions.question: look through
questions.answer: To examine or search through something.
questions.example: I looked through my old photos last weekend.
choices: To examine or search through something.
To use up all of something.

questions.question: take on
questions.answer: To accept responsibility or hire someone.
questions.example: The company will take on 50 new employees next month.
choices: To accept responsibility or hire someone.

questions.question: bring up
questions.answer: To mention or raise a topic.
questions.example: I need to bring up this problem with my manager.
choices: To mention or raise a topic.

questions.question: burn down
questions.answer: To destroy completely by fire.
questions.example: The fire burned down the entire forest.

questions.question: pick up
questions.answer: To collect or lift something.
questions.example: Can you pick me up at the airport tomorrow?

questions.question: knock down
questions.answer: To cause something to fall by hitting it.
questions.example: The storm knocked down many trees in the park.
choices: To cause something to fall by hitting it.

questions.question: fill out
questions.answer: To complete a form or document.
questions.example: I need to fill out this application form.
choices: To complete a form or document.

questions.question: call off
questions.answer: To cancel an event or activity.
questions.example: The concert was called off due to bad weather.
choices: To cancel an event or activity.

questions.question: work on
questions.answer: To spend time improving or fixing something.
questions.example: I worked on my homework after dinner.
choices: To spend time improving or fixing something.

questions.question: look into
questions.answer: To investigate or examine something.
questions.example: The police are looking into the robbery case.

questions.question: bring out
questions.answer: To release or publish something.
questions.example: The company brought out a new product line.

questions.question: go through
questions.answer: To examine or experience something.
questions.example: I need to go through these documents before the meeting.

questions.question: go up
questions.answer: To increase or rise.
questions.example: The price of gas went up again this month.

questions.question: give away
questions.answer: To donate or give something for free.
questions.example: I gave away my old clothes to charity.
choices: To donate or give something for free.

questions.question: run down
questions.answer: To lose power or become exhausted.
questions.example: The batteries in my phone ran down yesterday.
choices: To lose power or become exhausted.

questions.question: turn off
questions.answer: To deactivate or stop a device.
questions.example: I turned off my computer because it was frozen.
choices: To deactivate or stop a device.

questions.question: hand out
questions.answer: To distribute or give something to people.
questions.example: The teacher handed out the exam papers to the students.
choices: To distribute or give something to people.

questions.question: see through
questions.answer: To recognize deception or understand the truth.
questions.example: I saw through my friend's lie immediately.
choices: To recognize deception or understand the truth.

questions.question: tear down
questions.answer: To demolish or destroy a building.
questions.example: The old factory was torn down to make room for apartments.
choices: To demolish or destroy a building.

questions.question: break down
questions.answer: To stop working or to analyze something.
questions.example: My car broke down on the way to work.
choices: To stop working or to analyze something.

questions.question: come up
questions.answer: To arise or be mentioned.
questions.example: An important issue came up during the meeting.

questions.question: set up
questions.answer: To establish or arrange something.
questions.example: We need to set up a meeting for next week.

questions.question: show up
questions.answer: To arrive or appear.
questions.example: He didn't show up for the appointment.

questions.question: back up
questions.answer: To support or make a copy of data.
questions.example: Don't forget to back up your important files.
choices: To support or make a copy of data.

questions.question: cut down
questions.answer: To reduce or fell a tree.
questions.example: The doctor told him to cut down on sugar.
choices: To reduce or fell a tree.
To support or make a copy.

questions.question: find out
questions.answer: To discover or learn information.
questions.example: I need to find out some information about the new policy.

questions.question: call off
questions.answer: To cancel an event or activity.
questions.example: The rain caused the picnic to be called off.
choices: To cancel an event or activity.

questions.question: break away from
questions.answer: To leave or escape from someone or something that is holding you.
questions.example: She decided to break away from her old habits.
choices: To leave or escape from someone or something that is holding you.

questions.question: break down
questions.answer: To stop working or to analyze something.
questions.example: The computer suddenly broke down.
choices: To stop working or to analyze something.

questions.question: break up
questions.answer: To end a relationship.
questions.example: They broke up after five years of marriage.

questions.question: break into
questions.answer: To enter a place by force.
questions.example: The thief tried to break into the house.
choices: To enter a place by force.

questions.question: break out
questions.answer: To start suddenly (for something bad, like war, fire, etc.).
questions.example: War broke out between the two countries.
choices: To start suddenly (for something bad, like war, fire, etc.).

questions.question: drop off
questions.answer: To take someone or something to a place and leave them there.
questions.example: Can you drop me off at the mall?
choices: To take someone or something to a place and leave them there.
To enter a place by force.

questions.question: drop out
questions.answer: To stop participating or being involved.
questions.example: He decided to drop out of college.
choices: To stop participating or being involved.
To take someone to a place.
To enter a place by force.

questions.question: drop by
questions.answer: To visit someone for a short time.
questions.example: I'll drop by your house later today.
choices: To visit someone for a short time.
To take someone to a place.
To enter a place by force.

questions.question: show around
questions.answer: To give someone a tour of a place.
questions.example: The manager will show around the new employee tomorrow.
choices: To give someone a tour of a place.
To behave in a way to attract attention.

questions.question: show off
questions.answer: To behave in a way to attract attention.
questions.example: Don't show off in front of your friends.
choices: To behave in a way to attract attention.

questions.question: show up
questions.answer: To arrive or appear.
questions.example: She didn't show up to the party.
choices: To behave in a way to attract attention.

questions.question: go over
questions.answer: To review or check something carefully.
questions.example: The teacher will go over the homework tomorrow.
choices: To review or check something carefully.

questions.question: hang out
questions.answer: To spend time relaxing or socializing.
questions.example: I hung out with my friends last night.
choices: To spend time relaxing or socializing.

questions.question: hang up
questions.answer: To suspend something or end a phone call.
questions.example: Please hang up your dirty clothes.
choices: To suspend something or end a phone call.

questions.question: hang on
questions.answer: To wait for a short time.
questions.example: Hang on a minute, I'll be right there.
choices: To wait for a short time.

questions.question: close down
questions.answer: To stop operating permanently.
questions.example: The store will close down next month.

questions.question: closed off
questions.answer: To block an entrance or access.
questions.example: The police closed off the road due to an accident.
choices: To block an entrance or access.

questions.question: shut down
questions.answer: To stop operating or turn off.
questions.example: She shut down her business last year.
choices: To stop operating or turn off.

questions.question: shut up
questions.answer: To be quiet or stop talking.
questions.example: Please shut up the noise!
choices: To be quiet or stop talking.

questions.question: shut off
questions.answer: To turn off a device or stop the flow of something.
questions.example: Don't forget to shut off the lights.
choices: To turn off a device or stop the flow of something.

questions.question: clean up
questions.answer: To tidy or remove dirt and mess.
questions.example: I need to clean up this mess.
choices: To tidy or remove dirt and mess.

questions.question: cleaned out
questions.answer: To empty something completely.
questions.example: She cleaned out her closet yesterday.
choices: To tidy or remove dirt and mess.

questions.question: worked out
questions.answer: To have a good result or to exercise.
questions.example: The project worked out successfully.
choices: To have a good result or to exercise.

questions.question: work out
questions.answer: To exercise or solve a problem.
questions.example: I work out at the gym every morning.
choices: To exercise or solve a problem.

questions.question: working off
questions.answer: To get rid of something by using energy.
questions.example: The kids are working off too much energy.
choices: To get rid of something by using energy.

questions.question: come up with
questions.answer: To think of or produce an idea or solution.
questions.example: We need to come up with a solution to this problem.
choices: To think of or produce an idea or solution.

questions.question: coming down with
questions.answer: To become sick with an illness.
questions.example: I think I'm coming down with a cold.
choices: To become sick with an illness.

questions.question: come out with
questions.answer: To release or produce something.
questions.example: The company will come out with a new product next month.

questions.question: come over
questions.answer: To visit someone at their place.
questions.example: Would you like to come over for dinner?
choices: To visit someone at their place.

questions.question: come out
questions.answer: To become known or to appear.
questions.example: The truth will come out eventually.
choices: To become known or to appear.

questions.question: comes up
questions.answer: To arise or be mentioned.
questions.example: This topic comes up in every meeting.

questions.question: look over
questions.answer: To examine or review something.
questions.example: I need to look over my notes before the exam.

questions.question: look out
questions.answer: To be careful or pay attention to danger.
questions.example: Look out! There's a car coming.
choices: To be careful or pay attention to danger.

questions.question: takes after
questions.answer: To resemble a family member.
questions.example: He takes after his father in many ways.

questions.question: take back
questions.answer: To retract a statement or return something.
questions.example: I take back what I said about him.
choices: To retract a statement or return something.

questions.question: step down
questions.answer: To leave an important job or position.
questions.example: The CEO will step down next month.
choices: To leave an important job or position.

questions.question: step up
questions.answer: To take action when something needs to be done.
questions.example: Someone needs to step up and take responsibility.
choices: To take action when something needs to be done.

questions.question: step out
questions.answer: To leave a place for a short time.
questions.example: I need to step out for a moment.
choices: To leave a place for a short time.

questions.question: step in
questions.answer: To become involved in a difficult situation or replace someone.
questions.example: The substitute teacher will step in today.
choices: To become involved in a difficult situation or replace someone.

title: Phrasal Verbs Meanings
